doc.title: Asian Credit Strategy
doc.source_uri: 2025-08-29/Asia credit weekly spotlight week of 21 to 27 AugAsia credit weekly spotlight week of 21 to 27 Aug_2025-08-29

passages.text: WoW, Asia IG/HY widened 1bp each to 68bp/287bp, respectively. Within IG, Hong Kong IG remained unchanged at 67bp, turning out as the most resilient, and the rest widened 1- 4bp WoW. Within HY, India widened 5bp WoW to 297bp, due to strong performance in the previous weeks. The rest HY space tightened WoW, led by China HY property (- 29bp WoW to 1,019bp). Asia financial overall widened 2bp WoW to 86bp. This, with lower rates, led to a total return of \(+0.28\%\) for Asia IG, and \(+0.23\%\) for Asia HY. For WoW spread performance, see Exhibit 15 and "Relative value in charts."

Given the strong technicals and fundamentals, we expect overall credit spreads to stay resilient, under our base case of no rate cuts in rest of 2025. According to our latest Asian credit survey (see note), Investors have turned net Ow Asia credit at \(11\%\) in August vs net UW \(27\%\) in April, and most expect spreads to remain unchanged in the next 3mo/6mo/12mo period.

This week, Asia ex Japan & Australia saw US\\$3.0bn issuance \((+185\%\) WoW), half of which came from financial, and another half from non- financial corps. Japan issuance was strong in the week, mainly from IG corps (US\\$1.5bn), and US\\$0.5bn from financial. This brings the total APAC supply to US\\$5.0bn this week, \(+153\%\) WoW.
With no default this week, the LTM default rate by amount remained unchanged at \(0.4\%\) for APAC HY, and at \(0\%\) excluding CH RE.
Asia tech: Meituan 2Q25 results; S&P, Fitch revised SK Hynix's outlook to pos.; Moody's upgraded Xiaomi to Baa1 from Baa2; Baidu mulls dim sum bond issuance per Bloomberg.
Asia gaming: Wynn Macau announced to early redeem its USD1bn \(5.5\%\) \(26\) note at par on Sept 2. Macau's ADR during Aug 18- 24 was strong at MOP792mn, up by over \(20\%\)

CN industrial: GLP to obtain up to USD1.5bn investment from ADIA to support growth, and it also announced to get RMB2.5bn investment from Zhejiang gov't- affiliated entities to expand its China data center operations. WESCHI and H&H reported 1H25

earnings. WESCHI considers new bond issuance to address 2026 USD bond. CN property: As of Aug'25, 60 distressed developers reported progress on their debt restructuring, and 20 developers' restructuring plan were approved according to Yicai

media. Yuexiu is considering up to US\\$350mn 3Y CNH bond per Bloomberg. India corp: US raised tariffs on India to \(50\%\) ; Muthoot Finance issued USD600mn \(6.375\%\) 2030s notes; Fitch upgraded Muthoot to BB+ from BB with outlook at stable.
Positive rating actions on JSW Infrastructure (JSWINI) by Fitch & Moody's.
Other SEA: Medco upgraded to Ba3 (Moody's); Danantara mulls onshore bond issuance.
Australia corp: Santos extended the exclusivity period for the takeover led by XRG to Sep 19th. Results of Mineral Resources, Nickel Industries, Karoon Energy, Fortescue.

Trading ideas and investment strategies discussed herein may give rise to significant risk and are not suitable for all investors. Investors should have experience in relevant markets and the financial resources to absorb any losses arising from applying these ideas or strategies.

BofA Securities does and seeks to do business with issuers covered in its research reports. As a result, investors should be aware that the firm may have a conflict of interest that could affect the objectivity of this report. Investors should consider this report as only a single factor in making their investment decision.
Refer to important disclosures on page 26 to 29. Analyst Certification on page 24. Valuation & Risk on page 24.
Global Emerging Markets | Corporate Credit Asia

Asia financialThe Asian financial sector started to be active again in the last week of Aug. '25 along with most of the companies finished 2QFY25 result announcements. OCBcSP issued USD 1bn tier- 2 bond, OCBcSP 4.55 2035 call in Sept'30, with 10- year non- call 5- year bond structure. The bond was repriced at T+80bp with yield at 4.55%. Based on the relative valuation, we add coverage on the new tier- 2 with OW. Please see report: Add coverage on new OCBc tier- 2 with OW. As a frequent bond issuer, OCBcSP now has four tier- 2 bond outstanding with one USD 1bn tier- 2 bond to be called on Sept. 10th. Singapore banks reported solid fundamentals in 1H25 with the final Basel III implementation boosted the overall CET1 ratio by about 190bp on average, please see our report Banks - Singapore: 1H25 credit profile remains solid, but capital bonds appear expensive. Further, BOC Aviation Ltd (BOCAVI, not covered) issued USD 500mn, 5.5- year senior bond with credit rating at low single A. The bond is priced at 58bp with yield at 4.344%. The Chinese national bank's senior bond duration equivalent senior bond is about 35bp currently.

Asia technologyMeituan reported 2025 results with significant EBITDA drop on narrowed margins amid intensified competition. Company reported increased net cash position, stable gross leverage and lower debt/cap ratio. S&P revised SK Hynix's outlook to positive from stable and affirmed its BBB ratings, citing strong operating performance outlook and disciplined financial policy. Separately, Fitch also revised SK Hynix's outlook to positive from stable and affirmed its BBB ratings, citing its strengthening financial profile, robust market position and disciplined capex. Moody's upgraded Xiaomi to Baa1 from Baa2 with outlook revised to stable from positive, citing enhanced business profile following strong EV segment performance, solid financial profile and prudent investment strategy. Baidu is reported to consider another dim sum bond issuance per Bloomberg. JD.com's property investment arm, along with two other companies, plans to establish a Singapore- based real estate investment trust (REIT) with assets potentially valued at more than USD 1bn per Bloomberg.

China propertyMarket: As of Aug'25, 60 distressed developers reported progress on their debt restructuring, and 20 developers' restructuring plan were approved with debt amounted to c.RMB1.2tn according to Yicai media. Shanghai will no longer restrict the number of homes that eligible residents can purchase in the outer suburbs. Fund raising: Yuexiu is considering to raise up to US \(350mn through a 3Y CNH bond offering according to Bloomberg. Earnings: Developers reported 1H25 earnings in the past week: COLI reported EBITDA decline (- 28% YoY) on softer revenue and lower margins; it saw improved debt/cap and net gearing, but higher leverage. China Resources Land reported strong EBITDA growth (+37%YoY), while weaker debt/cap, net gearing and net leverage. Yuexiu had EBITDA weng down 6% YoY with improved debt/cap, but higher net gearing and leverage. Jinmao saw strong EBITDA growth (+40% YoY), and improved debt/cap, net gearing and net leverage. Greentown saw a 26% YoY EBITDA decline, stable debt/cap, but higher net gearing & net leverage. Vanke reported EBITDA down 39% YoY on lower revenue and margins; it saw stable debt/cap, but higher net gearing & net leverage.

Asian gamingBased on our equity colleague's industry check, Macau's ADR (average daily run- rate) during Aug 18- 24 was strong at MOP792mn, up by over 20% YoY and 8% better WoW, driven by mass segment. This suggests August GGR is on track for low to mid- teens % growth. Wynn Macau announced to early redeem its outstanding USD1bn 5.5% senior notes due in 2026 at par on Sept 2. SJM and Genting will report earnings on Aug 28 after market.

China industrialGLP announced to obtain up to USD1.5bn investment from Abu Dhabi Investment Authority (ADIA) to support its growth with initial capital deployment of USD500mn. Separately, GLP also announced to get RMB2.5bn investment from Zhejiang provincial government- affiliated entities to expand its China data- center operations. Fosun's healthcare arm licensed the international rights to one of its planned medications to UK biotech firm Sitala for up to US \(675mn. WESCHI and H&H reported 1H25 earnings this week. West China Cement (WESCHI) saw strong 25 EBITDA growth driven by higher China gross profit per ton and higher overseas volume; it saw higher debt but improving leverage. WESCHI expects to receive approval for its offshore issuance quota from the National Development and Reform Commission (NDRC) by late September according to REDD. H&H reported 1H25 EBITDA - 3% YoY/+35% HoH; it had positive free cash flow during 1H25 and lower net leverage.

U.S. raised the tariffs on Indian goods to \(50\%\) from \(25\%\) as punishment for buying Russian oil. Fitch affirmed India at BBB- with outlook at stable, citing its robust growth and solid external finances.

Muthoot Finance issued USD600mn \(6.375\%\) sinkable bonds due Mar'2030. We added coverage on MUTHIN 2030s with Ow on attractive valuation and upgraded MUTHIN 2029s to Ow as well from MW (see report). Separately, Fitch upgraded Muthoot Finance to BB+ from BB with outlook at stable, citing improvements in its credit profiles and supportive economic environment.

Fitch upgraded JSW Infrastructure (JSWINI) to BBB- from BB+ with outlook at stable, citing the strong financial profile backed by solid asset quality, resilient volume and financial disciplines. Separately, Moody's revised JSW Infrastructure outlook to positive from stable and affirmed its Ba1 ratings, citing its very strong financial performance.

Moody's upgraded Medco Energi to Ba3 from B1 and revised its outlook to stable from positive, citing tits improved capacity to absorb future acquisitions given its enhanced scale and solid credit profile.

Indonesia's sovereign wealth fund, Danantara, plans to raise IDR 50tn by selling patriot bonds in five- and seven- year parts with a \(2\%\) coupon, per Bloomberg. Separately, Danantara has signed a USD1.42bn agreement with Chinese company GEM Co. Ltd. to invest in battery- grade nickel plant, per Bloomberg.
The High Court of Kuching, Sarawak, adjourned the hearing by one month at the request of both Petronas and Sarawak- owned Petroleum Sarawak (Petros) to allow the negotiations to continue.

WOW, Asia IG/HY widened 1bp each to 68bp/287bp, respectively. Within IG, Hong Kong IG remained unchanged at 67bp, turning out as the most resilient, and the rest widened 1- 4bp WoW. Within HY, India HY widened 5bp WoW to 297bp, due to strong performance in the previous weeks. The rest HY space tightened WoW, led by China HY property (- 29bp WoW to 1,019bp). Asia financial overall widened 2bp WoW to 86bp. This, with lower rates, led to a total return of \(+0.28\%\) for Asia IG, and \(+0.23\%\) for Asia HY. For WoW spread performance, see Exhibit 15 and "Relative value in charts."

Given the strong technicals and fundamentals, we expect overall credit spreads to stay resilient, under our base case of no rate cuts in rest of 2025. According to our latest Asian credit survey (see note), Investors have turned net Ow Asia credit at \(11\%\) in August vs net Uw \(27\%\) in April, and most expect spreads to remain unchanged in the next 3mo/6mo/12mo period.

Weekly spread changes: WoW, Asia IG/HY widened 1bp each to 68bp/287bp, respectively. Within IG, Hong Kong IG remained unchanged at 67bp, turning out as the most resilient, and the rest widened 1- 4bp WoW. Within HY, India HY widened 5bp WoW to 297bp, due to strong performance in the previous weeks. The rest HY space tightened WoW, led by China HY property (- 29bp WoW to 1,019bp). Asia financial overall widened 2bp WoW to 86bp. For WoW spread performance, see Exhibit 15 and 'Relative value in charts."

Asia credit spread pick- up against US: In terms of spread performance, Asia IG performed in line with US IG, while Asia HY underperformed US HY. Looking at relative value, we note that Asia IG is trading 17bp tighter than US IG 5- to 7- year, vs. the 5- year average pick- up of +27bp. The pick- up of Asia HY over US HY widened 17bp WoW to 9bp, below 5- year average pick- up of +402bp. Asia HY excluding China property (including financial) is trading 33bp tighter than US HY, vs. the 5- year average pick- up of +93bp. A breakdown shows that Asia non- China HY is trading 1bp tighter than US HY, vs. the 5- year average pick- up of +110bp; and China non- property HY (corporates) is trading 4bp tighter than US HY, below the 5- year average pick- up of +330bp.

This week, the 5s10s curves flattened for Malay corp, Thai corp, China SOEs, and China AMCs, but steepened for India IG corp, Indo quasi, tech, and Australian bank. The 10s30s credit curves flattened for most sectors, except China SOEs. Among sectors, Indo quasi currently has the steepest 5s10s curves, followed by Hong Kong IG, China tech, India IG, Malaysia IG, and Australian bank, while China A SOEs and China AMCs have inverted curves. For10s30s, Indo quasi has the steepest curve, followed by China BBB SOEs, Malay IG, and Australian bank. Compared with the US, Asia curves are flatter than US IG non- financial for most sectors, except for Indo quasi and 10s30s China BBB SOEs and Malay IG.

We did not see defaults in the past week. As a result, LTM default rate by amount/count was unchanged at 0.6%/1.3% for Asia HY, and 0% for Asia HY excluding CH RE. For Australia and Japan, there have been no default cases the last 12 months. So, the default rate is lower for APAC HY than AXJ at 0.4%/1.2% by amount/count.
As of 29 Aug, Asia HY: \(0.6\%\) , China HY: \(1.7\%\) ; China HY property: \(5.7\%\) ; default rate has declined from high level in 2022- 23 due to China property crisis

Based on EPFR, from 21 to 26 Aug, Axj hard funds saw outflow of US\$1mn, vs. US\$193mn inflow in the previous week. All- EM hard funds saw inflow of US\$154mn, vs. US\$1.2bn inflow in the previous week. US IG funds saw US\$7.2bn inflow, lower than US\$10.5bn inflow in the previous week. However, US HY funds reported US\$188mn outflow, vs. US\$632mn outflow in the previous week. Year to date, US HY funds saw inflow of \(+7.6\%\) (as a \(\%\) of AUM at the year beginning), and US IG funds saw \(+6.0\%\) However, Axj hard funds saw outflow of \(- 8.7\%\) , and EM hard funds saw outflow of \(- 2.3\%\) . Note that EPFR mainly tracks retail flows, which is a small portion of Asia market.
Axj hard currency funds saw US\$1mn outflow this week (from 21 to 26 Aug), vs. US\$193mn inflow in the previous week, where we saw the highest weekly inflow since Feb 23
In YTD25, US HY funds saw inflow of \(+7.6\%\) of AUM, and US IG funds saw inflow of \(+6.0\%\) ; however, Axj hard currency saw outflow of \(- 8.7\%\) and EM hard currency saw outflow of \(- 2.3\%\)

We are OW on MUTHIN 29s/30s on attractive valuation against Asian BB+ peers. We are MW MUTHIN 28s despite tighter valuation given pick-up against India BB infrastructure peers and US BB index.

Upside risks: (1) uptick in gold loan demand, and (2) rise in domestic gold prices. Downside risks: (1) significant and sustained decline in gold prices, and (2) adverse changes in regulatory guidelines relating to gold loan NBFC.

The bank generally has better fundamentals than peers on its high loss absorption buffers through cycle, superior asset quality, and great business diversification of Great East Holding, one of the largest insurance group in the region. We are OW OCBCSP 4.55 2035 and OCBCSP 5.52 2034 on their attractive valuation vs. OCBCSP 4.602 2032/1.832 2030 (MW). OCBCSP'32/'30 is only fairly priced vs. DBSSP and UOBSP' tier- 2 bonds. The downside risks to our recommendations are: 1) commodity price volatility dampens the economy growth of Singapore and other ASEAN countries, 2) dramatic asset quality deterioration in Oil shore & Marine sector and housing sector amid economic slowdown, and 3) aggressive business expansion undermines capitalization and leads to more sub- debt supply. The upside risk to our recommendation is the business profile improves with extraordinary profit, which enhance the financial strengthen substantially.
Some of the securities discussed herein should only be considered for inclusion in accounts qualified for high risk investment.

BofA Global Research provides recommendations on an issuer's bonds (including corporate and sovereign external debt securities), loans, capital securities, equity preferreds and CDS as described below. Convertible securities are not rated. An issuer level recommendation may also be provided for an issuer as explained below. BofA Global Research credit recommendations are assigned using a three-month time horizon.

Issuer Recommendations: If an issuer credit recommendation is provided, it is applicable to bonds and capital securities of the issuer except bonds and capital securities specifically referenced in the report with a different credit recommendation. Where there is no issuer credit recommendation, only individual bonds and capital securities with specific recommendations are covered.Loans, CDS and equity preferreds are rated separately and issuer recommendations do not apply to them.

BoFA Global Research credit recommendations are assigned using a three- month time horizon: Overweight: Spreads and/or excess returns are likely to outperform the relevant and comparable market over the next three months. Marketweight: Spreads and/or excess returns are likely to perform in- line with the relevant and comparable market over the next three months. Underweight: Spreads and/or excess returns are likely to underperform the relevant and comparable market over the next three months.

BoFA Global Research uses the following rating system with respect to Credit Default Swaps (CDS): Buy Protection: Buy CDS, therefore going short credit risk. Neutral: No purchase or sale of CDS is recommended. Sell Protection: Sell CDS, therefore going long credit risk.
